author: DeliciouslyUnaware
body:
So SQ bought me a car but pypl plays bought me a $116k retirement fund. 

If you're new to pypl's earnings month heres the play: long pypl until Jan 20th then go with atm puts because it sells off into earnings every time. 

Dont hold anything through earnings. IV crush is brutal on this and the real rally/dips happen the following week.

Go long on calls Jan 31 and rise the wave.

Collect your tendies and toss a coin to your TA autist DeliciouslyUnaware.

Your Welcome.

author: jswats92
body:
How do you do your research?

I only do a surface quick search tbh. I look at comparable companies and see if there is any value in them and if they are priced fairly when compared to it.

I saw PayPal was way higher and thought to myself “wtf, why PayPal is so ancient I only use it for eBay which is rarely” eBay I think would be a good option player too. 

My other regret was CHD. I knew they were undervalued bought at $49ish and held for a year(with my luck it went down smh) as soon as it got to break even I sold. Today I think it’s at 70.... and I had a ton of stock with them.

author: Rageoftheage
body:
AI programs that will be used to trade securities need to consume massive amounts of data in order to learn and fine-tune themselves along with spotting emerging trends. Exchanges will own some of the most valuable data and analytics companies will get paid fortunes to process it. That's my rough draft of the future anyways.  


You can go to [dividend.com](https://dividend.com) and check the information on those stocks. SQ and PYPL dont pay dividends but all of the others do and they all have been increasing dividends consistently while still maintaining low p/e ratios. In the future shares bought now will most likely not only grow a great deal in nav price but also be paying massive dividends(think 100%+) on cost.

author: Looksking
body: Secular growth companies with a strong product or service based on growing themes. Today? AI/machine learning, rise of the middle class in the East ( think banks, insurance, consumer staples), robotics, healthcare. Companies such as Microsoft, Paypal, Unilever, Google, Twilio, Appen,  prefer companies with a ROIC > WACC, diversify, hold positions in different sectors. Expect to make some mistakes.

author: Excogitated
body:
Unfortunately, Bank of America apparently doesn't allow credit card payments from Sutton Bank. Hopefully will find a workaround.

PayPal and Amazon (Chase) cards seem to work so far.

author: rjm101
body:
>How do you deal with issues of fraud or theft?

Some people pay through paypal. thesilverforum has feedback like ebay so you can check their trade history.

Yes of course a dealer is going to be more trusted however there are plenty of regulars on the forum that have done a lot of trades for me to trust them but of course it's never going to be completely risk free. The price you pay is how much risk you're willing to take like with most things in the market. I've worked on getting a good track record for my trade history so that when I go to sell my precious metals I can provide some confidence to the buyer.

author: MadCritic
body:
Okay! Well you don't own my two biggest holdings, AMZN and GOOGL, so there's them. Getting into Mastercard or Visa wouldn't hurt either - I'd go for Mastercard personally. If you want an insurance company with stakes in Apple, KO and major banks you could go for BRK.B. I also have smaller holdings in Paypal and Enphase as I see great upside to them.

But if just two, AMZN and GOOGL.

author: PapaCharlie9
body:
Depends on what you mean by "best".

QQQ is not all tech, correct. Neither if VGT, if you ask me. 

https://www.zacks.com/funds/etf/QQQ/holding

https://www.zacks.com/funds/etf/VGT/holding

I don't think of Visa, Mastercard, and PayPal as tech companies. And yet "tech" does not include "biotech", despite some biotech companies behaving more like tech companies.

author: MarblesEye
body:
I stick to a very few stocks that I trade options on. I like to trade stocks I am familiar with and I listen to the news and try and capitalize on a company’s success or failures.  I only buy options. 

At the start of the year I was into financial payment processors and traded. VISA, PAYPAL , MASTERCARD

The last few quarters I only traded Tesla, Apple, SPY and Disney iv alway trades ROKU up until there was a big sell off. 

On my chart the periods that are flat I didn’t trade much or withdraw my profits. And most of the big down draws we’re options that I had 3-5 month out expiration and they had a big down draw. Eventually sticking it out some came back. 

The last down draw was me buying a Put option on Tesla after watching the CyberTruck reveal. The good news is it dropped and I was in the green. Bad news is I was banned from day trading and couldn’t pull out as it started to go back up in the same day. 


Currently I am holding Apple Calls that are doing very well. 


Was unsure how to post text in the post.

author: CowboyJimador
body:
You see payment apps equivalent to Venmo/Cashapp/Paypal in Asia that have really taken hold. For example, small street vendors are unable to take direct card payments, but an increasing number now accept direct payments via mobile payment apps.

I am not sure whether this model is applicable to more developed countries in the West. I can potentially see an expansion of Apple Pay/Facebook Pay to support direct consumer to firm payments without using debit/credit cards.
